text: I am delighted to be here today to talk
about NIH s remarkable journey to
leverage 21st century technology
advances accelerate biomedical research
discoveries and improve health let me
start by telling you a little bit about
NIH our thirty-five billion dollar
annual budget supports science research
by three hundred thousand researchers at
2,500 academic institutions and medical
centers located all around the United
States and around the world including at
our research labs on our campus in
nearby Bethesda Maryland we focus on
everything from the most basic science
about how life works to conducting
clinical trials and translating that
research to create new treatments and
cures recent advances we are seeing
through technology enabled research are
nothing short of amazing
today we're generating vast amounts of
biomedical research data and it's more
than doubling every year in fact the
cost of sequencing a human genome has
plunged to less than a thousand dollars
that is three million times less
expensive than the first completed human
genome just 15 short years ago these
technology advances have led to the rise
of new data domains at just
unprecedented size and scale genomics
and other types of ohmic data electronic
health record data imaging data such as
brain and chest scans environmental data
and even personal devices like my Fitbit
the one I'm wearing to track my exercise
this data deluge has led to many new big
data research programs where we're
seeing tremendous opportunities for
discovery but there are challenges
research data are siloed and they're
often difficult for researchers to find
or
use we have to figure out better more
cost-effective ways to sustain these
high-value data research components and
we must always protect the privacy and
security of your health data we're
investing a lot of effort to address
these challenges but make no mistake the
ability to harness and learn from data
in unprecedented ways coupled with these
new technologies aren't literally
changing the way we do science and we
know we can only achieve the kind of
advances we need through partnerships we
cannot do this alone
last year NIH launched the strides
initiative as part of our first-ever
strategic data science plan strides is a
set of new partnerships with industry
partners to harness the power of cloud
computing to provide NIH researchers
access to the most advanced
computational infrastructure tools and
services AWS joined our strides
initiative as a partner in October of
2018 and is helping us by providing
scalable storage elastic computing
resources advanced tools for data

learning and artificial intelligence
training programs an important component
on how researchers can use the AWS
platform for health research and
safeguards to secure and protect the

available through the cloud will be fair
findable accessible interoperable and
reusable to support researchers with all

scientists to the bioinformatics science
researcher through these partnerships
and investments in big data we believe
we can
we accelerate cures and treatments for
everyone I'd like to mention just a few
of the exciting big data research
programs NIH has underway as a
soon-to-be first time grandmother
I am proud that NIH funds four billion
dollars in pediatric research each year
to improve the lives of our most
important resource our children did you
know that one in 33 infants born in the

of our important pediatric programs kids
first is developing large-scale data

structural defects these capabilities
are allowing us to work at a very large

collaboratively empowering research for

overall cancer death rates have been

with cancer is still a reality for
millions of people in our country we
must do more the cancer moonshot program
is ambitious we're trying to accelerate
cancer research to achieve a decade's
worth of discovery and progress in just
five years one of the key initiatives in
this program is to build a national data
ecosystem to enable researchers to learn
more about how to murrs evolve to be
able to better predict treatment
outcomes
and to help address what are often
debilitating patient symptoms and side

appreciate the important role that AWS
has played in enabling this
computational infrastructure for cancer
research the third program is the brain
initiative which is set up to
revolutionize our understanding of the

enabling us to better diagnose treat

depression Parkinson's and Alzheimer's
alzheimer's is personal for me every 66
seconds someone in the United States is

was one of those people this is a moment

new technology capabilities are
dedicated in coordinated efforts can

program the all of us program is one of
the most ambitious research efforts our
nation has ever undertaken
we aim to collect a massive amount of

this is quite a departure from the

to come together to help change the

based on your help characteristics your
